Package com.github.tommyettinger.cringe

Class RandomDistinct64

java.lang.Object
java.util.Random
com.github.tommyettinger.cringe.GdxRandom
com.github.tommyettinger.cringe.RandomDistinct64
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Json.Serializable, Externalizable, Serializable, RandomGenerator
public class RandomDistinct64 extends GdxRandom
A variant on Java 8's SplittableRandom algorithm, removing the splittable quality so this has one possible stream. You'd typically use this when you want every output of nextLong() from one generator to be a different, unique number until every long has been generated, such as for generating unique seeds or IDs. The reasons for removing the splittable quality are a little complicated, but it's enough to say that by having a fixed stream, this is a little faster, and it avoids the possibility of some streams being lower-quality. This uses Pelle Evensen's Moremur mixer instead of SplittableRandom's Variant 13, which should give it roughly equivalent performance but somewhat higher statistical quality. Like many variations on SplittableRandom and its SplitMix64 algorithm, this changes its state by a simple counter with a large increment; one of the best increments seems to be (2 to the 64) divided by the golden ratio, plus or minus 1 to make it odd. This number, 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L or -7046029254386353131L when stored in a signed long, shows up a lot in random number generation and hashing fields because the golden ratio has some unique and helpful properties. The increment is sometimes called the "gamma," and this particular gamma is known to be high-quality, but of the over 9 quintillion possible odd-number gammas, not all are have such nice properties (for instance, 1 would make a terrible gamma if it were used in this generator, because it's so small). We only allow one gamma here, so we can be sure it works.
Other useful traits of this generator are that it has exactly one long of state, that all values are permitted for that state, and that you can skip(long) the state forwards or backwards in constant time. It is also quite fast, though not as fast as RandomAce320 on Java 16 or newer.
Unlike the multiple-state generators here, RandomDistinct64 tolerates being given sequential seeds and/or states, and in fact doesn't randomize the seed when given one with setSeed(long).
This class is a GdxRandom and is also a JDK Random as a result. This implements all methods from GdxRandom, including the optional skip(long) and previousLong() methods.
The SplitMix64 algorithm is derived from this paper by Guy L. Steele Jr., Doug Lea, and Christine H. Flood. Moremur was written by Pelle Evensen, and improves upon the MurmurHash3 mixer written by Austin Appleby.
To use this class in your code, you only need to copy RandomDistinct64.java and GdxRandom.java from this folder into any package in your codebase. They must be in the same package, but there are no other restrictions. You do not need to copy any other subclasses of GdxRandom if you are satisfied with this one.

    • nextLong

      public long nextLong()
      Description copied from class: GdxRandom
      Returns the next pseudorandom, uniformly distributed long value from this random number generator's sequence. The general contract of nextLong is that one long value is pseudorandomly generated and returned.
      The only methods that need to be implemented by this interface are this and GdxRandom.copy(), though other methods can be implemented as appropriate for generators that, for instance, natively produce ints rather than longs.
      Specified by:
      nextLong in interface RandomGenerator
      Specified by:
      nextLong in class GdxRandom
      Returns:
      the next pseudorandom, uniformly distributed long value from this random number generator's sequence

    • skip

      public long skip(long advance)
      Skips the state forward or backwards by the given advance, then returns the result of nextLong() at the same point in the sequence. If advance is 1, this is equivalent to nextLong(). If advance is 0, this returns the same long as the previous call to the generator (if it called nextLong()), and doesn't change the state. If advance is -1, this moves the state backwards and produces the long before the last one generated by nextLong(). More positive numbers move the state further ahead, and more negative numbers move the state further behind; all of these take constant time.
      Overrides:
      skip in class GdxRandom
      Parameters:
      advance - how many steps to advance the state before generating a long
      Returns:
      a random long by the same algorithm as nextLong(), using the appropriately-advanced state

    • previousLong

      public long previousLong()
      Description copied from class: GdxRandom
      Optional; moves the state to its previous value and returns the previous long that would have been produced by GdxRandom.nextLong(). This is often equivalent to calling GdxRandom.skip(long) with -1L, but not always; some generators can't efficiently skip long distances, but can step back by one value.

      The public implementation calls GdxRandom.skip(long) with -1L, and if skip() has not been implemented differently, then it will throw an UnsupportedOperationException.

      Overrides:
      previousLong in class GdxRandom
      Returns:
      the previous number this would have produced with GdxRandom.nextLong()

    • next

      public int next(int bits)
      Description copied from class: GdxRandom
      Generates the next pseudorandom number with a specific maximum size in bits (not a max number). If you want to get a random number in a range, you should usually use GdxRandom.nextInt(int) instead. For some specific cases, this method is more efficient and less biased than GdxRandom.nextInt(int). For bits values between 1 and 30, this should be similar in effect to nextInt(1 << bits); though it won't typically produce the same values, they will have the correct range. If bits is 31, this can return any non-negative int; note that nextInt(1 << 31) won't behave this way because 1 << 31 is negative. If bits is 32 (or 0), this can return any int.
      The general contract of next is that it returns an int value and if the argument bits is between 1 and 32 (inclusive), then that many low-order bits of the returned value will be (approximately) independently chosen bit values, each of which is (approximately) equally likely to be 0 or 1.
      This method is protected in Random, but is public here because there are legitimate uses when you want a random number that fits exactly inside a power-of-two size. For example, when you want to be able to receive any non-negative int, you can call next(31) (this doesn't work with GdxRandom.nextInt(int)).
      Note that you can give this values for bits that are outside its expected range of 1 to 32, but the value used, as long as bits is positive, will effectively be bits % 32. As stated before, a value of 0 for bits is the same as a value of 32.
      Overrides:
      next in class GdxRandom
      Parameters:
      bits - the amount of random bits to request, from 1 to 32
      Returns:
      the next pseudorandom value from this random number generator's sequence

    • copy

      public RandomDistinct64 copy()
      Description copied from class: GdxRandom
      Creates a new GdxRandom with identical states to this one, so if the same GdxRandom methods are called on this object and its copy (in the same order), the same outputs will be produced. This is not guaranteed to copy the inherited state of any parent class, so if you call methods that are only implemented by a superclass (like Random) and not this one, the results may differ. It is strongly suggested that subclasses return their own class and not GdxRandom.
      Specified by:
      copy in class GdxRandom
      Returns:
      a deep copy of this GdxRandom.
